Utilize the power of the human mind: Without books, humanity could tap into its innate ability to retain and share knowledge through oral tradition, personal experience, and direct mentorship. This could involve storytelling, cultural preservation, and hands-on learning.

Harness the power of technology: In the absence of books, technology could play a crucial role in preserving and disseminating knowledge. For instance, virtual reality and augmented reality technologies could create immersive learning experiences, while AI-powered chatbots could facilitate access to information.

Foster a culture of apprenticeship: In the absence of written records, a new system of apprenticeship could emerge, where individuals learn from experienced craftspeople, artisans, or experts in their field. This would allow for the transfer of skills and knowledge through hands-on experience and direct mentorship.

Develop new forms of documentation: Without books, new forms of documentation could evolve, such as audio or video recordings, 3D models, or even performance art. These formats could capture knowledge and preserve it for future generations.

Embrace the power of nature: In a world without books, people could turn to nature as a source of knowledge. By studying the patterns and rhythms of the natural world, humans could gain insights into the interconnectedness of all things and develop a deeper understanding of the world around them. This could involve observing the cycles of the seasons, the migration patterns of animals, or the patterns of the stars in the night sky.
